sample.title: Exclusive Preview: The Hidden Cost of South Sudan’s Oil Boom
sample.description:
Watch the full episode exclusively on Bloomberg: http://www.bloomberg.com/short-documentaries

South Sudan relies on oil for almost all of its revenue. But some communities living near the oil fields allege polluted water is causing birth defects and miscarriages, raising questions over health and responsibility.

sample.title: What Gold’s Rise (Really) Means for the World
sample.description:
Gold’s price per ounce surged past $4,000 this month, a record-breaking rally tied in part to eroding confidence in the US dollar. Uncertainty driven by Donald Trump’s trade war as well as questions about the independence of the Federal Reserve and America’s wavering economy have also played a part. Add to that heightened geopolitical tensions across the globe and you have a recipe for a mass flight to gold. And that’s exactly what central banks and investors have been doing. 

Now with China seeking to offer an alternative to American dominance, we look at what gold’s historic rise means for the global financial system. 

Sign up for the Economics Daily newsletter to discover what's driving the global economy and what it means for policy makers, businesses, investors and you.
https://www.bloomberg.com/account/newsletters/new-economy-daily

sample.title: Why younger Americans are saving money at such a high rate
sample.description:
As Americans live longer and worry about outlasting their money in retirement, a growing number are counting on one strategy for their future financial security: working longer.

Roughly 70% of U.S. workers who haven’t retired yet have considered pushing back their retirement date, according to a recent survey from F&G, an insurance company. Nearly half of the 2,000 adults surveyed said they’re afraid they won’t have enough money to retire.

sample.title: The $1 Trillion Tangled Web Of AI Deals Mapped Out
sample.description:
The pace and scale of artificial intelligence infrastructure deals lately has been staggering, with OpenAI, the maker of ChatGPT, alone racking up around one trillion dollars worth of AI deals this year. These interconnected investments between companies like Nvidia, Oracle, Broadcom, CoreWeave, Meta, Google, AMD, Microsoft and others have dramatically lifted the valuations of many of the companies involved and sent U.S. stock indexes soaring. But some experts are worried that this tangled web of deals is reminiscent of the dotcom bubble.

Produced by: Magdalena Petrova
Animation: Christina Locopo
Additional Reporting: Kif Lewsing, Ashley Capoot, Mackenzie Sigalos
Edited by: Erin Black
Senior Director of Video: Jeniece Pettitt
Additional Footage: Getty Images

sample.title: Why The AI Boom Might Be A Bubble?
sample.description:
Artificial intelligence is driving a wave of corporate investment unlike any in decades, with forecasts calling for $500 billion in global AI spending by 2026. Experts describe this as a "capex supercycle," but warn it may be propping up an otherwise fragile U.S. economy. If AI spending slows or fails to deliver on its promise, the consequences could ripple through markets, employment and economic growth.

2:11 What happens if AI spending slows?
4:14 AI CapEx Supercycle
5:56 An uneven economic recovery

sample.title: What the U.S. can learn from Canada's banking system
sample.description:
FDIC data shows that the U.S. has nearly 4,500 banks. Canada has only 79 banks, according to the Canadian Bankers Association.

However, America’s banking industry is consolidating. FDIC-insured banks in the U.S. are down by nearly half since 2005.

sample.title: How Costco’s Clothing Business Became Bigger Than Abercrombie And Gap
sample.description:
Clothing may not be the first thing that comes to mind when shoppers think about Costco, but its apparel sales are more than some of the biggest brands like Calvin Klein, Tommy Hilfiger and Old Navy. It has grown the category more than 40% over the past five years, which is significantly more than its competitors Sam’s Club and BJ’s. Costco has even now found itself facing a lawsuit by Lululemon for allegedly “duping” its products.  Watch the video to learn how Costco has become a major player in the fashion world.

Chapters:
0:00 Introduction
0:50 Chapter 1: Clothing boom
3:10 Chapter 2: Kirkland fandom
6:00 Chapter 3: Cheap prices, big profits

sample.title: CNBC All-America Economic Survey: Americans' views on the economy turned more negative in Q3
sample.description: 42% of Americans approve of President Donald Trump’s handling of the economy, according to the latest CNBC All-America Economic Survey. Overall, the survey found Americans' views of the economy turned more negative in the third quarter, as inflation, a softening labor market and government shutdown fueled concerns about the broader outlook.

sample.title: Opening Bell: October 17, 2025
sample.description: Watch the opening bell at the Nasdaq and New York Stock Exchange for October 17, 2025.

sample.title: AerCap CEO on Spirit Airlines' struggles
sample.description: AerCap CEO Aengus Kelly said Friday that the antitrust lawsuit over the Spirit–JetBlue merger was the biggest challenge Spirit has faced amid its recent struggles, noting that the case took roughly two years to resolve and negatively affected both business operations and employee morale.

sample.title: AerCap CEO: Airlines are buying more used planes as industry faces supply and durability issues
sample.description: AerCap CEO Aengus Kelly told CNBC on Friday that he is seeing more airlines buying used planes, as they are able to spend more time in the air before needing maintenance. He said while newer, more advanced engines are more efficient, they are much more fragile, which is a problem engine manufacturers are spending billions to solve.

sample.title: Sen. MarkWayne Mullin: Shutdown is costing us close to $1B a day to do nothing
sample.description: Sen. MarkWayne Mullin (R-Okla.) joins 'Squawk Box' to discuss the state of the ongoing federal government shutdown, sticking points in negotiations, and more.

sample.title: Journalists leave Pentagon over reporting restrictions. #US #Pentagon #BBCNews
Gaza Humanitarian Foundation stops operations after ceasefire | BBC News
sample.description:
The controversial US and Israeli-backed Gaza Humanitarian Foundation (GHF) has confirmed it is suspending operations in Gaza after the ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas came into effect last Friday.
 
Despite being funded until November, the organisation said its final delivery was on Friday.
 
The GHF has been heavily criticised after hundreds of Palestinians were killed while collecting food near its distribution sites. Witnesses say most were killed by Israeli forces.
 
Israel has regularly denied that its troops fired on civilians at or near the sites and the GHF has maintained that aid distribution at its sites has been carried out "without incident".

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#GHF #BBCNews

sample.title: What are the Tomahawk missiles Ukraine wants? | BBC News
sample.description:
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky is meeting with US President Donald Trump in Washington on Friday, as Trump weighs whether to arm Ukraine with Tomahawk missiles capable of striking deep into Russia.
 
Zelensky has called on the US to provide Ukraine with the advanced missiles, which have a range of 2,500 km (1,500 miles).
 
Asked earlier this week if Trump was considering giving Ukraine Tomahawks, he said: "We'll see... I may."
 
But asked about the same prospect after a call with Putin, Trump said "we can't deplete" the US stockpile of Tomahawks, adding "we need them too... so I don't know what we can do about that".

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#Tomahawk #Ukraine #BBCNews
